author: 孙玥
title: 齐鲁工业大学一作品获全国大学生能源经济学术创意大赛总决赛特等奖_中国网
text:
近日，第十一届全国大学生能源经济学术创意大赛总决赛在山西太原落下帷幕，齐鲁工业大学（山东省科学院）环境科学与工程学部龚梦、许可、马梦霞、朱玥颖4位学生共同完成的作品《建材行业典型节能技术对降碳及经济性影响》荣获特等奖。指导老师闫桂焕、许崇庆获评“优秀指导教师”。
据悉，本届大赛组委会共收到来自全国724所高校的31388支队伍报名参赛，仅55项作品获得全国特等奖，获特等奖率仅0．18％。（来源：齐鲁工业大学）
近日，第十一届全国大学生能源经济学术创意大赛总决赛在山西太原落下帷幕，齐鲁工业大学（山东省科学院）环境科学与工程学部龚梦、许可、马梦霞、朱玥颖4位学生共同完成的作品《建材行业典型节能技术对降碳及经济性影响》荣获特等奖。指导老师闫桂焕、许崇庆获评“优秀指导教师”。
据悉，本届大赛组委会共收到来自全国724所高校的31388支队伍报名参赛，仅55项作品获得全国特等奖，获特等奖率仅0．18％。（来源：齐鲁工业大学）

author: Syndicated Content
title: Factbox-India’s struggles with high rape cases, low conviction rates
text:
By Shivam Patel
NEW DELHI (Reuters) – The rape and murder of a trainee doctor in Kolkata last week has brought women onto the streets across India, furious at persistently high levels of sexual violence despite legal reforms and promised crackdowns.
The government brought in sweeping changes to the criminal justice system, including tougher sentences, after the gang-rape and murder of a 23-year-old in 2012. But campaigners say little has changed.
Below are some details of the scale of the crisis and the challenges ahead.
NUMBERS HIGH
Around the time of the 2012 attack, police were recording up to 25,000 rape cases a year across India, according to data from the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB).
Since then, the annual number has largely remained above 30,000, barring the COVID-19 pandemic year of 2020, which saw a sharp fall.
Attacks peaked at nearly 39,000 in 2016. In 2018, on average one woman reported a rape every 15 minutes across the country, according to a government report.
There were more than 31,000 reported rapes in 2022, the latest year for which data is available.
The numbers have stayed persistently high, even as the authorities ramped up the penalties, including a minimum sentence of 10 years with a possible extension to life – or the death penalty if the victim is younger than 12.
Other legal reforms have included widening the definition of rape to include non-penetrative acts, bringing in fast-track courts and reducing the age threshold so 16-year-olds can be tried as adults for such offences.
Senior criminal lawyer Rebecca M. John, who has represented many rape victims, says some rapists still believe they can get away with their crime.
“One of the factors would be the absence of fear of the law,” she told Reuters.
“There is no consistent application of the law, that’s one aspect. There is very poor policing, that’s another aspect.”
CONVICTIONS LOW
Conviction rates for rape ranged between 27%-28% from 2018-2022, according to NCRB data.
Over much of that time, that was second lowest rate out of five serious crimes, also including murder, kidnapping, rioting and causing grievous hurt.
The lawyer, John, said some judges had become more reluctant to convict since the tougher sentences came in.
“If a judge feels that there is some doubt and he’s pushing somebody away for life without remission, or maybe even death, on evidence which doesn’t stand up to judicial scrutiny, not entirely at least, then he’s compelled to acquit,” she said.
“Whereas if he had some discretion in the matter, he could have lowered the sentence, ensure that he’s convicted.”
MAJOR CASES SINCE 2012
A number of highly publicised cases have kept the crisis in the headlines since 2013.
In 2018 a 26-year-old man in central India was sentenced to death three weeks after his arrest on charges of rape and murder of a baby girl.
In 2019, police officers shot dead four men suspected of raping and killing a 27-year-old veterinarian near southern city of Hyderabad. The men had been in police custody and officers said they were shot dead near the scene of the crime where they tried to snatch the weapons of accompanying policemen.
The 2020 gang-rape of a 19-year-old girl in northern India’s Hathras district and her death weeks later in a hospital triggered nationwide outrage.
(Reporting by Shivam Patel; Editing by Andrew Heavens)

author: @ukrinform
title: Russian shelling kills two, injures six in Donetsk region over past day
text:
Russian shelling kills two, injures six in Donetsk region over past day
Ukrinform
On June 11, Russian forces killed two civilians and injured six others in Ukraine's eastern Donetsk region, according to Vadym Filashkin, head of the Donetsk Regional Military Administration.
In a post on Facebook, Filashkin reported that one person was killed in the village of Raiske and another in Toretsk. Six more civilians across the region sustained injuries due to Russian attacks.
He said that the reported casualty figures -- 3,254 killed and 7,293 injured -- do not include data from Mariupol and Volnovakha, which remain inaccessible for accurate reporting.
Russians attacked resident of Havrilivka in Kherson region with drone
As previously reported, 168 children are still residing in areas of the Donetsk region where mandatory evacuations of families with children are ongoing.

author: @atribunasantos
title: Tribuna do Leitor: sexta-feira, 29 de dezembro de 2023
text: Shows, clima e rotina Confirmada a causa da morte da fã da cantora Taylor Swift no show do Rio de Janeiro: exaustão devido ao calor excessivo – algo lógico, pois ocorreu na onda de calor, evento que deve se tornar cada vez mais frequente no futuro próximo. Este ano, a participação do El Niño potencializou os efeitos desse nefasto evento climático. Novidade? Depende. Para os organizadores do show, foi algo inédito em décadas de atuação. Já para a ONG Amigos da Água, a crise da água e a emergência climática fazem parte do rol de alertas que a entidade emite à sociedade há 24 anos. Organizadores de shows e autoridades terão de incluir em suas agendas de responsabilidade socioambiental a emergência climática a fim de que se tenha mais cuidado na farta e ampla distribuição de água a seus clientes! Rodolfo José Bonafim - Santos Manchete que mancha Veículo jornalístico de grande penetração nacional estampou nesta semana a seguinte manchete: “Natal tem pior venda em três anos, aponta Serasa”. O WhatsApp quase colapsou e os leitores de manchetes fizeram críticas ao governo, pois a manchete dava munição para esses detratores. Algo não batia com tal notícia, pois as vendas on-line estavam no topo das preferências. Pelo que se via nos corredores dos shoppings nos telejornais e se lia, inclusive aqui em A Tribuna, as compras de Natal estavam aquecidas. Mas o mistério foi desfeito, em um trecho perdido no meio de um parágrafo: “compras em cartão de débito ou crédito e Pix não são termômetro nessa pesquisa”. Marcus Aurelio de Carvalho - Santos Remoção de árvore No dia 18, solicitei à Ouvidoria a remoção de um tronco de árvore de cerca de três metros de altura que está infestado de cupins, ameaçando cair sobre os carros ou até mesmo de minha residência. Para minha surpresa, a Secretária das Prefeituras Regionais de Santos indeferiu meu pedido, alegando se tratar de área particular, cujo responsável pelo manejo arbóreo é o proprietário da área. Solicito a revisão do meu pedido, pois a área é pública e a própria Prefeitura podou a árvore anos atrás, deixando somente um enorme tronco, agora condenado e ameaçando cair sobre minha residência. Se a área fosse particular, a Prefeitura não faria melhorias no local nem varreria toda semana o espaço. Silvio Rodrigues - Santos Homenagem Na semana passada, houve uma justa homenagem ao diretor-presidente da TV Tribuna e ex-presidente da Associação Comercial de Santos (ACS), Roberto Clemente Santini. Também merecem os parabéns o artista Paulo Frade, que fez um lindo retrato, agora exposto na galeria da ACS, e a jornalista Ravena Soares, pela reportagem no jornal A Tribuna. Grupo de Proteção da Família e da Cidadania Luisa Baptista O atropelamento criminoso da atleta olímpica Luisa Baptista em São Carlos prova que o crime no Brasil compensa. Quem vai pagar todo prejuízo de uma vida dura dedicada ao esporte? A atleta estava treinando e não media esforços para alcançar suas metas. E agora, ministro da Justiça, que adora dar uma de machão: onde está? O Brasil nunca será sério e os nossos políticos so pensam nos bolsos deles. Zureia Baruch Jr. - São Paulo Resposta Em resposta aos leitores Toshio Shiokawa e Cesar Tavares Cunha, a Prefeitura de Santos esclarece que o projeto Levante a Partir das Calçadas, em discussão na Câmara, foi criado para integrar a ampla política voltada ao resgate da população em situação de rua. A proposta foi inspirada no conceito housing first (moradia primeiro) já adotado em vários países e, inclusive, em cidades brasileiras como Recife e, mais recentemente, São Paulo. O projeto santista será voltado apenas a pessoas em situação de rua já assistidas e devidamente acompanhadas pela Secretaria de Desenvolvimento Social. O benefício mensal de R$ 660 terá destino exclusivo para auxílio-aluguel e estará condicionado à participação nos programas de capacitação profissional realizados nas Vilas Criativas. Nos 12 meses definidos como duração do benefício, estas duas comprovações - pagamento do aluguel e frequência na capacitação - serão feitas mensalmente, além do acompanhamento por psicólogos e assistentes sociais da Prefeitura. Ressaltamos ainda que, inicialmente, serão apenas dez beneficiários e, de acordo com projeto de lei, poderão ser ampliados até o limite de 50. A proposta também resultará economia ao Município, uma vez que cada vaga em abrigo custa, em média, R$ 2,2 mil por mês. Por fim, a Prefeitura destaca que o programa não será uma ação isolada: acontecerá em paralelo às outras ações já adotadas, como a ampliação das vagas em abrigos, reforço das equipes da abordagem social (que podem ser acionadas pelo telefone 153) e o recâmbio qualificado que, só neste ano, já possibilitou que 300 pessoas em situação de rua em Santos retornaram aos seus municípios de origem. Diretoria de Comunicação da Prefeitura de Santos

author: VNExplorer
title: Inside the 'most viewed' houses in each Australian capital city for 2023: A breathtaking country estate, a beachside home with a 'crazy' floorplan and a bachelor pad with an amusing feature
text:
Domain revealed the most clicked-on listings in Australia this yearWhile some are luxury dream homes, others are far from what you'd expect READ MORE: Breathtaking country home with a lavish bar, sunken firepit and a sparkling pool
The most sought-after homes for Australian property buyers in 2023 have been revealed – and some of them are far from what you might expect.
Real estate marketplace Domain shared the most ‘clicked on’ properties for sale this year in each capital city, nationally and regionally and stand-outs ranged from bachelor pads to hinterland mansions and even a church.
The most-viewed property both in Melbourne and all of Australia was at 14 Charming Street in Hampton East, which was freshly renovated this year on hit TV show The Block by WA couple Kyle and Leslie.
Regionally, house hunters were loving a lavish country estate in Noosa’s hinterland while a spectacular and chic multimillion-dollar home caught Brisbane buyer’s attention.
There were some bizarre inclusions on the most viewed list including a country church with a graveyard in Hobart and a small apartment in Darwin where the bedroom sits right next to the bathtub.
There was also a former nursing house turned home which has a crazy floor plan with 19 bedrooms and a bachelor pad in Sydney’s south with a glass-walled garage and study perfect for car enthusiasts.
The most sought-after homes for Australian property buyers in 2023 have been revealed – and some of them are far from what you might expect
The most-viewed property both in Melbourne and all of Australia was at 14 Charming Street in Hampton East (pictured), which was freshly renovated this year on hit TV show The Block by WA couple Kyle and Leslie
This chic multimillion-dollar home in Chandler caught Brisbane’s attention in 2023. It boasts luxury features including an infinity-edge pool, sauna, wine cellar, high-end bar and water-surrounded conversation pit
AUSTRALIA (CITIES) AND MELBOURNE – CHARMING STREET, HAMPTON EAST
Charming Street in Hampton East gained national attention this year after The Block Season 19 saw five couples renovate and auction off properties – but it was the home at number 14 that was the Australian public’s favourite.
The spotlight put the street on the radar of many home buyers with searches and listing views skyrocketing on the website. 14 Charming Street had 50 per cent more clicks than its closest Block rival.
After 12 weeks of transforming the 1950s-built house into a modern masterpiece, Kyle and Leslie’s home was auctioned off for $3.1million during The Block’s season finale in November.
The street frontage has a minimalist design while inside is a light-filled haven with a very stylish and contemporary design.
Curved details feature throughout the chic home including in the dreamy main bedroom where a palette of whites and creams create a calming atmosphere.
Charming Street in Hampton East gained national attention this year after The Block Season 19 saw five couples renovate and auction off properties – but it was the home at number 14 that was the Australian public’s favourite
The spotlight put the street on the radar of many home buyers with searches and listing views skyrocketing on the website. 14 Charming Street had 50 per cent more clicks than its closest Block rival
AUSTRALIA (REGIONAL) – COOROY MOUNTAIN ROAD, COOROY MOUNTAIN
Set in the rolling green hills just west of Noosa is the breathtaking ‘Stonelea’ country estate with an (understandably) huge price tag.
A grand entry terrace welcomes guests into the show-stopping home complete with a library, an underground games lounge, a wine cellar, a private gym with a steam room as well as a walk-in wardrobe bigger than the master bedroom.
Lines between the indoor and outdoors are seamlessly blurred with a huge terrace wrapping around the entire upper level.
The entertaining terrace is like a high-end alfresco living room with a stone fireplace, vaulted ceilings and elegant pendant lights as well as jaw-dropping views over the infinity edge pool to the mountains towards the ocean.
Stonelea is still up for sale having been on the market since early October with a whopping $17.5million asking price. It was last sold in 2013 for $4.475million.
Set in the rolling green hills just west of Noosa is the breathtaking ‘Stonelea’ country estate with an (understandably) huge price tag
A grand entry terrace welcomes guests into the show-stopping home complete with a library, an underground games lounge, a wine cellar, a private gym with a steam room as well as a walk-in wardrobe bigger than the master bedroom
Stonelea is still up for sale having been on the market since early October with a whopping $17.5million asking price. It was last sold in 2013 for $4.475million
SYDNEY – PLANE TREE DRIVE, NARELLAN VALE
Narellan Vale, 60km south-west from the Sydney city centre, was on the radar of property hunters this year.
This unassuming home with quirky features sold for the exact $1.45million asking price back in June.
The funky four-bedroom pad was described as an ‘entertainer’s paradise’ and boasts a bright red kitchen, a kaleidoscopic mural and a display garage with a study inside so the previous owner could gaze at his car while working.
Listing agent Darrel Stenhouse of McLaren Real Estate – Narellan told FEMAIL the Plane Tree Drive home sparked a curiosity among home hunters for its ‘tacky but fun’ details.
‘It’s not the wow-est, most beautiful home I’ve sold all year, far from it in fact, but it was those differences that made people click,’ he said.
‘There are glass walls into the garages, black bedrooms and greenery everywhere. You could call it a little tacky but it created interest.’
Darrel was flooded with phone calls about the home he said appealed to interested buyers for its large 900sqm block and two garages.
‘The aspect of it being in a residential area with a six-car parking ability, from a genuine buyer’s perspective that was truly it,’ he said.
‘The rest of the clicks we got I think is because of the presentation online and the difference. People were looking at it saying ‘Wow, this is certainly not my cup of tea but I have to look even if I’m not interested’. That was the feedback I was getting.’
Way out in Sydney’s south west, 60km from the city centre in Narellan Vale is an unassuming home with quirky features that sold for ‘bang on’ it’s $1.45million asking price back in June
The funky four-bedroom pad was described as an ‘entertainer’s paradise’ and boasts a bright red kitchen, a kaleidoscopic mural and a display garage with a study inside so the previous owner could gaze at his car while working
‘It’s not the wow-est, most beautiful home I’ve sold all year, far from it in fact, but it was those differences that made people click,’ agent Darrel Stenhouse said
BRISBANE – LONDON ROAD, CHANDLER
A multimillion-dollar home sitting on a leafy sprawling estate boasts luxury features including an infinity-edge pool, sauna, wine cellar, high-end bar and water-surrounded conversation pit.
The incredible property, known as Stonebrook, looks like it is nestled in the countryside; however, it is situated in the south-eastern Brisbane suburb of Chandler, 16km from the city’s centre, or a half-hour drive.
When the spectacular home hit the market in July, buyers were in a frenzy and agents were inundated with inquiries as the property is expected to fetch a record-breaking price upwards of $20million.
Stonebrook’s design was inspired by an African Safari Lodge and holiday villas from Queenstown in New Zealand with striking black structures and stone walls and chimneys.
Inside feels like a high-end hotel thanks to its opulent rustic-chic design, cosy bedrooms, lavish bathrooms and a jaw-dropping bar in the billiards room which was modelled off the iconic Raffles Hotel in Singapore.
A multimillion-dollar home sitting on a leafy sprawling estate boasts luxury features including an infinity-edge pool, sauna, wine cellar, high-end bar and water-surrounded conversation pit
The incredible property, known as Stonebrook, looks like it is nestled in the countryside; however, it is situated in the south-eastern Brisbane suburb of Chandler, 16km from the city’s centre, or a half-hour drive
When the spectacular home hit the market in July, buyers were in a frenzy and agents were inundated with inquiries as the property is expected to fetch a record-breaking price upwards of $20million
PERTH – CHALMERS STREET, FREMANTLE
Inside an austere grey brick structure lies a stunning industrial-style home built by an award-winning architect that fetched $1.23million back in April.
The edgy three-bedroom pad is in the sought-after port city Fremantle in Perth’s south and was described as ‘Australia’s most private home’ thanks to its concrete slab-like facade that doesn’t even provide a glimpse into the rooms or yard.
Guests lucky enough to be invited inside the walls are greeted by lush and grassy gardens among a series of outdoor entertaining spaces.
Inside has a moody colour palette of greys, whites and blacks with abstract architectural elements throughout crafted by Fremantle firm spaceagency.
A low lying window in the lounge allows for light to come into the lounge will offering privacy from the street while a soaring double-height void provides a sense of grandeur.
Inside an austere grey brick structure lies a stunning industrial-style home built by an award-winning architect that fetched $1.23million back in April. It was dubbed ‘Australia’s most private home’ thanks to its concrete slab-like facade
A low lying window in the lounge allows for light to come into the lounge will offering privacy from the street while a soaring double-height void provides a sense of grandeur
Inside has a moody colour palette of greys, whites and blacks with abstract architectural elements throughout crafted by Fremantle firm spaceagency
HOBART – LAWITTA ROAD, LAWITTA
One of the most unique properties buyers were drawn to in 2023 is an old church that comes with a very spooky inclusion.
The historical country chapel was in search of a creative buyer who could converted it into a livable cottage as it had no bedrooms, bathrooms or even running water – but it does have its very own cemetery.
‘The new purchaser will need to make an application to become the new Cemetery Manager as per the Burial & Cremations Act 2019 to be endorsed as the new caretaker of this special property,’ the listing read.
Tombstones lie around the sandstone chapel marking ‘the many people from all walks of life who have been laid to rest in the peaceful cemetery’.
The 1837-built church is an open plan space with Gothic features sitting on a huge 4,047sqm lot in the rural locality Lawitta, 38km outside Hobart.
One of the most unique properties buyers were drawn to in 2023 is an old church that comes with a very spooky inclusion. Tombstones mark ‘the many people from all walks of life who have been laid to rest in the peaceful cemetery’
‘The new purchaser will need to make an application to become the new Cemetery Manager as per the Burial & Cremations Act 2019 to be endorsed as the new caretaker of this special property,’ the listing read
The historical country chapel was in search of a creative buyer who could converted it into a livable cottage as it had no bedrooms, bathrooms or even running water
ADELAIDE – KAURI PARADE, SEACLIFF
A one-of-a-kind residence in coastal suburb of Seacliff in Adelaide’s south drew in the clicks for its crazy floor plan.
The old house, set upon a large 900sqm allotment, used to be a nursing home so features a whopping 19 bedrooms and a maze of bathrooms, lounges, kitchens, studies, sunrooms and laundries.
It also captured the attention of thousands on Reddit who debated whether the layout was real.
Agent James Packham of Harcourts is an ‘expert’ in all forms of multiple occupancy dwellings and told FEMAIL property gathered attention because of the ‘diverse options’ it presented.
‘It had previously been a retirement home and as a result had an uncommonly large volume number of rooms. This drew interest from people with a view to create a rooming house or a supported independent living house,’ he said.
‘It was also subdivisible and in a great area being west of Brighton Road, Seacliff. We also ran an extensive social media campaign which drove traffic back to the website.
The property fetched a $1.1million sale price.
‘Ultimately the property was purchased by a local builder developer who subdivided the property into two regular shaped allotments for resale,’ James said.
A one-of-a-kind residence in coastal suburb of Seacliff in Adelaide’s south drew in the clicks for its crazy floor plan. The old house used to be a nursing home so features a whopping 19 bedrooms
Agent James Packham of Harcourts is an ‘expert’ in all forms of multiple occupancy dwellings and told FEMAIL property gathered attention because of the diverse options it presented
The property fetched a $1.1million sale price. ‘Ultimately the property was purchased by a local builder developer who subdivided the property into two regular shaped allotments for resale,’ James said
DARWIN – CAVENAGH STREET, DARWIN CITY
An unlikely home topped Darwin’s list as the most clicked-on property this year.
The studio penthouse apartment sits in the middle of Darwin and sold for a modest $180,000 in June.
Its unusual floor plan may have intrigued house hunters as the bathroom and bedroom are combined into one. A vanity and spa bath/shower sits right next to where the bed would go.
The bath is separated from the kitchen by a partition wall and while the space is small it fits a laundry cupboard, built-in wardrobes, a dining area and a balcony without feeling too cramped.
A balcony offers views over the city and glimpses of the ocean towards Mindil Beach while its location is perfect for those who want to be close to shops, bars and cafes.
An unlikely home topped Darwin’s list for most-clicked on property in 2023. A studio penthouse apartment that sits in the middle of Darwin unusual floor plan may have intrigued house hunters as the bathroom and bedroom are combined into one
The bath is separated from the kitchen by a partition wall and while the space is small it fits a laundry cupboard, built-in wardrobes, a dining area and a balcony without feeling too cramped
CANBERRA – LOIS SIMPSON CRESCENT, WHITLAM
The most viewed listing in Canberra in 2023 wasn’t a house but an empty street that will soon be filled with stylish family homes.
Lois Simpson Crescent sits on the edge of a new housing estate Whitlam in the Molongo Valley, 15 minutes west of Canberra’s CBD.
House and land packages are priced between $499,000 and $1.299million. One lot sold in 2023 for $460,000 back in April.
The ultra-chic design of the homes on offer caught buyers’ eyes.
Sleek white marble adorns the kitchen with elegant gold tapware while a freestanding bathtub in the bathroom adds a touch of luxury.
House and land packages are an appealing way for first home buyers and investors to get their foot in the property market and move straight into a brand new home that is low maintenance.
The most viewed listing in Canberra in 2023 wasn’t a house but a empty street that will soon be filled with stylish family homes. House and land packages available are priced between $499,000 and $1.299million

author: Tori Otten
title: GOP Congressman Says Absolutely Sick Thing About Dead Palestinian Babies
text:
GOP Congressman Says Dead Palestinian Babies Aren’t All That Innocent
Republican Representative Brian Mast is questioning the innocence of babies killed in Gaza.
A Republican representative believes that Palestinian babies are not innocent civilians but “terrorists” who should be killed.
Florida Representative Brian Mast made the horrifying comment when confronted by Code Pink protesters outside his office on Wednesday.
In a video, Mast can be seen calmly telling the demonstrators, “It would be better if you kill all the terrorists and kill everyone who are supporters.”
When asked if he has seen the images of Palestinian babies killed in Israeli attacks, Mast says, “These are not innocent Palestinian civilians.”
“The babies?” the activists asks in astonishment.
Mast then says that the “half a million people starving to death” should have elected a pro-Israel government.
When one protester points out that much of Gaza’s infrastructure has been destroyed, Mast says, “And there’s more infrastructure that needs to be destroyed.”
“Did you not hear me? There’s more that needs to be destroyed,” he says again for emphasis.
More than
27,000 Palestinians have been killed since October in Israel’s constant bombardment of Gaza. The majority of the victims have been women and children.
Mast’s horrific comments—and the chilling way in which he delivered them—should come as no surprise. In November, just a few weeks after the war began, Mast
compared Palestinian civilians to Nazis and implied that they are all guilty for Hamas’s atrocities.
“I would encourage the other side to not so lightly throw around the idea of ‘innocent Palestinian civilians,’ as is frequently said,” he said on the House floor.
“I don’t think we would so lightly throw around the term ‘innocent Nazi civilians’ during World War II.”

author: Destinee Scott
title: Psst: I Found a Secret SkinCeuticals Sale on the Brand's Most Coveted Products (Yep, Including the C E Ferulic Serum)
text:
When it comes to skincare, you usually get what you pay for. Which is why, all too often, some of the most raved-about products are also among the priciest. Case in point: the oh-so-coveted line of products from SkinCeuticals. Plenty of buyers, including PureWow Wellness Director Sarah Stiefvater, swear by the brand's offerings, from the A.G.E. Interrupter Advanced anti-wrinkle cream ($185; $157) (which she reviewed) to the cult-favorite SkinCeuticals C E Ferulic serum ($182; $155). They certainly cost a pretty penny, so I always wait for a (rare) SkinCeuticals sale to stock up for the season. Fortunately for me—and you—I found a secret one happening at Dermstore this week. From now through Nov. 8, you can use coupon code SKINC15 at checkout to secure 15 percent off a bunch of the brand's best sellers, including the cream that made Stiefvater put off her Botox appointment.
Trust me, you won't see the brand marked down again for quite a while, so without further ado, here are five SkinCeuticals products worth snapping up before this private sale is over.
Want to know which buzzy products are *really* worth buying? Sign up for our shopping newsletter to uncover our favorite finds.

author: CMS Medios
title: Galilea Montijo confiesa que lloraba por bullying en redes sociales | El Informador
text: Para Galilea Montijo, la gente en las redes sociales es muy cruel, sobre todo cuando se trata de hablar de los cuerpos ajenos, en su caso, recuerda lo mal que la pasó después de estar embarazada y sumarse al proyecto de "Pequeños gigantes". La conductora de "Hoy" habló en el matutino de Televisa de aquel difícil momento en el que comenzaban las redes sociales y el ataque hacia su figura fue brutal."A los 20 días después de que tuve a Mateo, estaba todavía con las grapas de la cesárea, estaba haciendo 'Pequeños Gigantes' y los comentarios eran horribles, hirientes, yo lloraba", reveló. Dijo que ella fue quien quiso unirse al proyecto después de dar a luz, sin embargo, recibió mucho "hate" que la puso mal anímicamente. "No lo volvería a hacer (conducir un programa). Vengo de una escuela donde me enseñaron que aunque te duela la cabeza o tengas problemas, hay que estar en el trabajo siempre presente. Vengo de la escuela del compromiso a mi trabajo, de la disciplina", admitió. Galilea Montijo recordó que la presión por evitar las críticas negativas la llevaron a someterse a una estricta dieta con la que bajó 15 kilos en un mes después de haber dado a luz."Me sometí a una dieta espantosísima en la que bajé 15 kilos en un mes luego del embarazo. Gracias a Dios pude amamantar porque no bajó la producción de leche, digo, gracias a Dios porque creo que me hubiera ido peor haberme sometido a una dieta tan dura, tan fuerte", detalló.Montijo, de 50 años, actualmente mantiene un romance con el modelo español Isaac Moreno, después de divorciarse de su esposo, el político Fernando Reina, con quien tiene un hijo. Galilea confesó estar sensible por su hijo, actualmente de 11 años, por lo que no pudo evitar llorar al recordar cuando estaba embarazada; aseguró que sin duda esos kilos de más que ganó cuando se embarazó de Mateo, han sido los mejores kilos de su vida. La conductora busca ser mamá por segunda ocasión, le gustaría tener una niña y ya revisa opciones para volver a ser madre a sus 50 años.***Mantente al día con las noticias, únete a nuestro canal oficial de WhatsAppFA

author: Ahmet Safa
title: GTA 6’s rival turns out to be a Russian crypto scammer!
text:
Released two months ago, Paradise was billed as a giant open-world game that could rival GTA 6. However, behind the impressive, albeit unspectacular, footage, some very suspicious details have emerged. According to YouTuber Jetro and other researchers, many elements used in the game’s trailer were purchased from the Unreal Engine Assets Store or copied from other games. Here are the details…
Paradise: GTA 6 alternative or Russian crypto scam?
Let’s start with the trailer. First of all, elements such as vehicles and brands seen in the trailer are allegedly unlicensed. In addition, many influencers who are listed as advertising collaborators on the game’s official website have stated that they have no connection to this project.
Although the game’s website lists an office address in Hong Kong, it turns out that this address is not correct. Ultra Games Ltd. says the office is located elsewhere, but refuses to share a precise location. The elements seen in the trailer will not appear in the final game. However, the main point of interest is the allegations that this game is a cryptocurrency-focused scam as much as its existence.
The cryptocurrency, called ParadiseTap ($PAR), is distributed via Telegram and can supposedly be used to buy items in the game or redeem them for real money. Currently, $100,000 $PAR is worth about $500. So it is very likely that this system is a fraud network designed to attract investors.
The fact that the game is listed on Steam still raises questions about its existence. It is unclear whether Paradise is actually a game or just a trailer project. So for now, more information is needed to understand whether Paradise is real or just an investment trap.
